title: Make the site go live (production deployment on Internet Computer)

requirements.text: Add production deployment documentation that explains exactly how to deploy the app to the Internet Computer mainnet, including: prerequisites (dfx), building the frontend assets, deploying canisters to the `ic` network, and where to find the resulting live URL(s).
acceptanceCriteria: A new deployment guide file exists in the repo (e.g., DEPLOYMENT.md or README section) written in English.
The guide includes step-by-step commands for deploying to mainnet (e.g., `dfx deploy --network ic`) and any required build steps.
The guide explains how to obtain the live canister URL(s) after deployment (asset canister and, if applicable, backend canister).

requirements.text: Ensure the project has a clean production build path: frontend builds without development-only assumptions, and can be served from an IC assets canister (deep links load the SPA correctly).
acceptanceCriteria: A production build of the frontend completes successfully.
When hosted from the assets canister, loading the root route renders the app successfully.
Refreshing the page on the app does not return a 404 (SPA routing is compatible with IC asset hosting, even if the app only uses a single route).

requirements.text: Confirm backend canister deployment readiness: the Motoko canister compiles and deploys to mainnet even if it is currently minimal/empty.
acceptanceCriteria: The backend canister compiles successfully with `dfx build`.
Deploying to mainnet does not fail due to missing candid/actor configuration or build errors.

constraints: Do not edit files under frontend/src/components/ui (read-only Shadcn components).
Do not edit immutable hook/entry files: frontend/src/hooks/useInternetIdentity.ts, frontend/src/hooks/useInternetIdentity.tsx, frontend/src/hooks/useActor.ts, frontend/src/main.tsx.
Backend must remain a single Motoko actor in backend/main.mo; only add migration.mo if an upgrade requires state migration.
nonGoals: Implementing CI/CD pipelines (e.g., GitHub Actions) unless explicitly requested.
Integrating external hosting providers (AWS/Vercel/Netlify) or non-IC deployment targets.
Adding new product features unrelated to deployment (e.g., new app screens, auth flows, databases).
